user_review: I ordered the Pad Thai for delivery via UberEats. The meal came quickly and was exactly as I expected. The portion is generous and filling, and comes with vegan shrimp, vegan chicken, fried tofu, and ground peanuts. ChuChai has an extensive menu with a wide array of mock meats and seafood, noodle dishes, appetizers, etc. Although everything is vegan, it's still hearty, delicious, and authentic Thai food - none of that kale and avocado BS. I highly recommend this restaurant.

Vegan in Montreal: a must visit for any veg fans in Montreal, and everyone else too! //The food here is absolutely amazing, and a really special treat with some unique options for those focusing on the vegan side of life. I went with a non-veggie person and we both enjoyed our meal so much. I friend insisted we try the "duck"...  and they were right! We added dumplings, imperial rolls, and "shrimp" and each dish was excellent. Overall can't recommend enough.

First of all, I did not realize that this restaurant only served vegan food until I got the menu. Although I am not a vegan, it did not stop me from ordering their food. We ordered spring roll, pad thai, which has vegan shrimp and vegan chicken and panang curry with vegan beef. I was really curious about vegan shrimp. The flavor of the dishes were pretty good, but I've had better Thai food before. The texture of vegan shrimp was interesting since I've never encountered them before. I think they did a good job at creating vegan versions those shrimp and meat. We sat out on the patio... it was just nice to be out in nice weather, eating good food. Food 3/5 but overall experience 4/5.

Every time that i'm in town, i always make sure to go at least once but always end up going a few times. We do have a few favorite dishes on the menu that is a must every time that we go like the fried seaweed, the papaya salad, the boeuf 3 sauce and the tofu with fried spinach and peanut sauce. I have brought a lot of people that weren't vegetarian to this restaurant and everyone was always super happy with the food. Great place for vegan, vegetarians or omnivores.

Another interesting vegetarian Asian fine dining restaurant that I see pop up in trendy areas all around the world. My family were the only Asian family that night so it was telling who the restaurant caters to. The food is hit or miss and like most of these types of places focus on imitating meat. Portions were generally small. One thing I did like was that you don't get the pungent smell and taste of fish sauce that is so heavily used in Thai cuisine. Some of the dishes like the rice and pad thai were overly sweet though without that saltiness mask. The crispy duck matched the texture of the meat and fat without the accompanying fatty taste and was done better than many other places. The dumplings in peanut sauce were just too sweet. Everything else was comparable to the cheaper mom & pop vegetarian places around the world.

Best vegan Thai place in Montreal. Great portions and service, the cocktails are great here especially matched with their spicy meals. I like to go here late nights because it gets crowded at early dinner time.  I often get the tofu drunken noodle (pad Thai) and it never disappoints!!

Went here for a family dinner on a cold night. One half of the place is reserved for the restaurant and the other half is reserved for the bar. Didn't really know what to expect since everything was vegan and it took a while for me to choose what I wanted off the menu. Our table ended up ordering a bunch of different things to share which was a good way to taste a little bit of everything. My favourites were the 3 flavours vegan beef, the crispy vegan duck and the fried rice. The sauces on these dishes were EXCELLENT and really brought it all together.Overall this place exceeded my expectations and I enjoyed my food.

Finding good vegan asian cuisine is usually a challenge for me. Thank goodness for this Montreal gem. ChuChai offers some of the tastiest meals I've ever enjoyed. The meals feel very upscale in their offering, presentation and portion sizes. We decided on 3 meals to share and found that it was enough for our appetites. The first dish we tried was the Pad Thai with duck. The Pad Thai did not disappoint and although I was discouraged by no offering of vegan shrimp with the dish the duck also did not disappoint. It was delicious and eerily reminiscent of real duck. I was impressed with the skill in the preparation and the taste. The second dish was the Chicken Chili and Basil. It was a succulent dish and the basil was very flavourful adding to the dishes overall enjoyment and appeal. Again the preparation of the chicken was good enough to fool even the most hard core of carnivores. There were many times I was questioning if we were indeed eating vegan meat.The last dish we got was the Duck with Soya and Spinach. This was my favourite of the night. The duck was crispy, sticky, tender and slippery. The sauce and glaze just added to the potency of the flavour experience. I could not get enough of it and my taste buds wanted to override my stomach capacity it was that good.I don't think that there is a menu item that you can go wrong with here. My only piece of advice is that all items on the menu come as described so if you want a rice or noodle dish to pair with it make sure you order that as well.
Overpriced, dishes didn't even include rice. Panang beef should be called "puke beef". Why bother naming things after meat anyway? You made your choice, vegans!

My Favourite restaurant in Canada!!! I would travel Montreal for a dinner here. I crave to eat here.Being a Vegetarian, I adored the concept of Vegan meat that they are trying to simulate. Mind blowing food.Pick any dish from the menu, no risk!!!Not to be missed ones are: Crispy Seaweed, Panang Beef Curry, Crispy Duck, Pad kee MaoAt times we take their 50 $ tasting menu, which is awesome.None of the Thai Restaurants around the world can beat its flavourful food!!! Every dish is a delicacy and with your first bite, there would be explosion of flavours, perfectly blended.... Every item is better than the other.. Gosh! This place turns me on!! Heavenly food, their servers are smart and hospitality is best in Montreal. Location St. Dennis again great! But parking would be a fight, do make a reservation, its always full; even on weekdays. Best for special occasions.. Bit expensive but worth it. Must go and try. No trip to Montreal for me is complete without a visit to Chu Chai.

Very unique but amazing restaurant.I tried a few tapas, a main and a few desserts.I don't want to give you any spoilers but everything was amazing!I will definitely go back to try more of the menuHighly recommended

Amazing Thai Food. The food here is as consistent and as delicious as it gets. I have been here probably over a 100 times and have never been disappointed. It is a fine dine restaurant and it is vegan. I have brought friends here who are hardcore non-vegetarians and they have had a hard time believing what they ate was not meat.I have tried probably everything on their menu like especially like cripsy seaweed, crispy duck with spinach, Panang beef curry, Pad kee mow, crispy rice.If you're a foodie (like me) this is one place you can't afford to miss. You can thank me later and I do accept cheques (or you can just like my post if you agree afterwards) :)
My favorite in Montreal. Try the crispy duck.  Delicious. Or any chicken dish. (Its all mock meat don't worry.)Just delicious.

Wow, didn't know that an all vegan place can create dishes that even better than meat dishes. Surprised and delighted to enjoy the several dishes we ordered. What could have been better was the environment, but you cannot choose who you sit next to at the restaurant. Overall, besides that, I have to give it 5 stars. I just cannot believe how these dishes were so rich in flavors.

One of the vegan Thai places ! Don't get confused with the names.. everything is vegetable, tofu and potato based. This place is one of a kind. We ordered the veggie noodles and rice and it was just classic. The drinks are surely something to try as well.. very exotic. There were some with a mix of spice sweet and sour - packed with flavor !

First thing: Im not veganSo when a starving meat lover needs food, it better be good and filling so this place blew my mind. A couple of my friends are vegan - you know, the cool kind who dont bust meat lover's chops ... so I trusted them when they said this place was great. Im really open to trying vegan restos. I love trying new things.I got chicken pad thai and I could hardly taste the difference between real chicken and chicken flavoured tofu.  I was so impressed!!! I was expecting something with a not so usual but tolerable after taste but it wasnt the case ( that probrably doesnt even make sense but wtv ). It was tasty and bursting with flavour Its definitely a good place for a Vegan to bring non vegan friends and everyone is happy. Vegans get to do their vegan thing and meat lovers will feel completely satisfied. I would definitely come back here!

I was invited here by a vegan friend while I was staying in Montreal. Even though I am a meat lover and intolerant to soy, I enjoyed the food in this place! There were plenty of tasty vegetable options!  There drink menu was very creative and the outdoor area on this traditional Montréal street was lovely!
this is a do not miss! They do a great job on faking you out with the meats and seafood and their four2K drink is AWESOME, never had anything like that ever. Great fresh food and great service.

Going to say the first time I came here with a large group I was really disappointed . They punish you if you come with a lager group .They forced you to order from a different menu that costed more and has a lot less to chose from , when I asked for a different menu they told me they could not do it out of laziness it's to much work for the  . Second time my friend really interested on trying it again just the 2 of us . The menu was a lot better more to choose from and better choices and priced food. First time here I took the Famous fake Duck plate YUK! Second time I had this fresh pita like thing friend recommended it was amazing . Then ordered the fake shrimp plate which was also really good . Original I was going to give this place 2 stars having more better choice for better price turned it to 4.

The food was good, but I was expecting more with everyone raving about it (I didn't have the crispy duck I guess that's why). Ive had better pad thai and red curry, even vegetarian versions. The service was a bit disappointing, not that the servers were bad but they seemed understaffed. Also received my cocktails towards the mid/end of the meal, probably because of the same.

Phenomenal Thai food! Incredible flavors and vegan to boot. Definitely more interesting than our Thai places back in NYC, and so nice to have a whole menu of veggie food to choose from instead of one or two options.

I had very high expectation for this restaurant because all my friends told me how good it is. I have to agree that for a vegetarian restaurant, it tasted pretty good. It's totally different from the typical vegetarian restaurant that we have in mind. It's flavourful! However, the service was slow and took forever before someone comes to get our order... Had to wait at least 1h30 after seated down to get my meal...

I'm a meat lover but boy oh boy was this ggrreeeatttt! The succulent crispy duck was quite an unbelievably extraordinary dish that had the perfect amount of cripsyness . The pad thai was arguably the best I've ever had and the red curry chicken was super duper flavourful. YUMMY YUMMY IN MA TUMMY. Keep up the great and innovative dishes

We passed by this Thai restaurant as we were walking along Rue Duluth.  We noticed high ratings on Yelp and decided to give it a try.  This restaurant is all vegan.  At first my carnivore husband wasn't sure, but they he decided to give it a try.  They had fake meat made out of soy.We ordered the following:- Kary Puff (Crispy pastry filled with vegetables and yellow curry): DELICIOUS- Red Curry with vegetables: This was a bit spicy for me.  The waiter was nice enough to take it back and made it mild.  The curry was very flavorful and I absolutely enjoyed it.Overall, a great place for some vegetarian food.

This place was UN REAL!!!! The decor is very evening appropriate (it's quite dark) but very nice. The service was good and the food was un. Believable. SO. GOOD!! I got a dish with vegan duck and I swear if someone would of told me it's real duck I would of believed them. The prices are reasonable and the portions are generous. I highly recommend this place for vegans and non-vegans, I think anyone would love it.

First off- the food was awesome. We ordered the crispy duck and the sweet and sour fennel salad with crispy chicken. Both were incredibly tasty and I'm not even typically fond of mock meats. In that sense I'd pick ChuChai over Yuan any day.The stinker with this place is that the service was seriously compromised. To be fair, we made our reservation super last minute for the end of service on a Friday night. When we arrived the host was wringing his hands telling us that a group of 30 was about to arrive. Oh boy. Service was super sporadic throughout the evening and we never received one of our plates. When we mentioned it to the server they weren't particularly phased and began to slam the kitchen staff. We were hoping to order another round of drinks, maybe even a coffee, but were very quickly ushered out once our dessert plate was cleared.We walked away from ChuChai still kinda hungry. I don't know if that's a attributable to the food or just the fact that we didn't get a third of what we ordered. I'd maybe venture back on a quiet night.

ChuChai is my go-to vegetarian place to take non-vegetarians, and my favourite restaurant in Montreal at this point.Honestly, I've taken, at last count, 12 non-veg guests there, and every single person has loved it.Their prices are on the upper end of causal dining, a three person outing is likely going to come in ~$100, more with drinks.Almost everything on the menu is great, but the favourites seem to be the faux crispy duck, the panaag curry, the crispy spinach and the sticky rice.I've never tired their desert offerings, however, as at the overall price of the meal there is usually a better offering elsewhere on St.Denis for desert, at a more friendly price point.Definitely call in advance and reserve a table or you might be out of luck.

Pretty tasty vegan Thai food but overpriced for the quality. I don't feel like there's much craftsmanship to the food here, at least not enough to justify the hype. I enjoyed most of what I tried but wasn't blown away.To start, the tom yum was yummy but the chicken satay was small and too sweet for my taste. The pad Thai was good, with the massaman curry being the unanimous favorite. My biggest complaint: I hate having to pay extra for rice when the dish is already expensive - of course I want rice with my curry?I expect restaurants at this price point to veer away from such faux meat-heavy dishes as it feels like a cheap cop out, but I'm sure others feel differently. To be fair, my partner loved everything we ate - but this isn't their review.One funny thing to note: We chose to eat on the edge of the covered terrace even though it looked like rain. When the host sat us, she warned us she couldn't guarantee a table inside - even though it was 100% empty at the time. Kinda strange but ¯\_(ツ)_/¯  everything turned out fine.

First of all I wish to say that ChuChai is strictly vegan.I had supper there. The food and service are very good although the vegan meat does not taste like meat at all. The sauces are great and so are the desserts. I did find it a little pricey though. $50 per person with 1 glass of wine, appetizer, meal, rice and dessert.
Everyone orders the duck but they're right. It's amazing. And yet the spicy basil chicken is probably better. My favorite Montreal vegetarian place.

I came here for my friend's birthday last weekend. I had been here before, a good 8 years ago and the menu was relatively the same. They are all Asian based dishes. The spice star level indicated on the menu isn't really reliable. I had a 1 star spicy dish and it wasn't even spicy. My husband tried the spiciest item on the menu: Vietnamese salad at 3 stars. It was medium spicy.For the dish you get, it's expensive. I had the `beef with bell pepper` for $19. There was maybe 1/4 of a bell pepper with about a dozen mini mini meat balls slathered in a sticky and overbearingly sweet sauce. It's a pain that the rice costs extra so it can absorb all that sugar.At least my Thaijito was good...

Everything is easy at ChuChai because it's all vegan. I started with the Tom Kha soup with vegetables; it was just the right spice level and warm and comforting. Next, I split the mango, green apple and cashew salad with a friend. Served on a bed of greens, it was pretty tasty. Lastly, the pad Thai was good, but I'm generally a bit underwhelmed by mock meat. Next time, I'd order it with tofu only and skip out on the mock chicken and shrimp. The restaurant itself is very nice, casual but beautiful and has fantastic service.

Fun, original, full of taste and an exciting menu. I brought my mother who is not vegetarian at all and she loved the "fake meat" plates she took. She even wants to bring a friend of hers! And visually, the plates makes you want to try it all!!!And their exotic drinks...to try!---Amusant, original et plain de goût. J'y ai amené ma mère qui n,es aucunement végétarienne et elle a adorés ses plats "de fausses viandes". Elle veut même faire découvrir le resto à une amie!Et visuellement les plats ne font que désirer de les essayer tous! Et vous devez essayer leurs boissons exotiques!

Wow super satisfied!! I was extremely surprise that their wh0leMenu is vegan and i was happy to taste the mushroom appetizer that taste so good i thought it was meat at first but i was told it was mushroom and it was absolutely delicious!! I tried the tofu with peanut sauce and fried spinach and the green curry veggies with coconut milk and it was so good with the side of brown rice and the coconut shred appetizer was served in a little leafy if was the perfect salty sweet balance i just love this place will be back! The japonaise beer was also very refreshing a d our waitress was super kind and gave good recommendation!!

My spouse chose this restaurant based on the high reviews. We're vegan and he loves Thai so it seemed perfect. Before seating us, the host decided to take a lengthy phone call. After he hung up, he told us we could eat there if we were out within an hour and a half because we didn't have reservations (fine with me).  It took half an hour before the same person took our drink order because the other servers just ignored us. We decided to leave after being rudely told that no, the expensive curry does not come with any rice. I have no problem paying more for fine food. After all, it's an experience. But there is no excuse for that level of rudeness.Perhaps we just came on an "off" night, or perhaps the 5 star reviews of this place were written by employees.

My wife and I enjoyed every dish and kept wondering how they accomplished both flavor and texture for our dishes. I really was amazed at the duck like texture, crispy chewy with a little effort needed for gamey meat.   If I lived in Montreal this would become one of our favorite go to places.  This not a specialty restaurant but it should be valued as an upscale foodie spot that is worth the uber money to get her. If your coming from old town.. take another uber up to the nearby outdoor market on your first days visit to the city and you'll set the bar high for the rest of your visit!

Funny enough, we picked this spot for dinner based on rating and craving Thai. When we arrived, although we did not have a reservation, they found us a table right away (and outside to enjoy the weather, yay!) in the midst of a very hectic busy period.  So we were off to a good start.  Now for the funny part...we had no idea it was a vegan restaurant!  My hubs loves meat and so I initially felt bad until we ordered and then thoroughly enjoyed our meal!  We had veggie spring rolls to start (peanut sauce to die for). Hubs had crispy duck and enjoyed it. I had tofu peanut curry (kinda like penang curry) and I was dreaming about it for days after.  Wine selection was decent (for what can be expected at a Thai resto) and the service was A+!

Absolutely hands down the best vegetarian restaurants, especially if you like Thai food. Everything was so delicious... The mushooms, papaya salad we're both amazing appetizers. the crispy fried duck was literally one of the best dishes I've had in an incredibly long time.  Everything is vegan yet the texture and flavor is so close to the real thing. The service was impeccable as well. Will definitely go back again.
Would I return? probably not. Was the food good? meh. Nothing that I would rave about.

I'm going to give it a star, not because the food wasn't amazing (it was great), but because of the staff acting childish. When we left, the waitress took the bill and showed it to their colleagues and they were having giggles over it for some reason. Perhaps they were shocked we left tip, I don't know, I couldn't understand them. But either way, this is something that's very rude and unnaceptable, I'm not coming there again.

I wish I knew about this restaurant before! Vegan-Vegetarian Asian restaurant with faux meat and fish. Absolutely delicious veg cuisine that is unlike anything I've had anywhere else. We tried the chicken tom yum soup, salt and pepper "shrimps", crispy spinach, a thai "beef"dish, pad thai with "chicken"- excellent food!! The service was great, ambience amazing. This restaurant definitely tops my list for vegetarian options.

Not impressed. I didn't really like it last time, and got dragged again by my vegetarian / vegan friends. I thought that I played it safe with my order of crispy duck and sticky rice, but for $30 after tax and tip, I could do better in almost any other place around the neighbourhood. My friends loved it; I was the minority opinion... But I like what I like! (and I don't like the food here, not for this price, for sure!)

I don't typically frequent vegan restos, however this is a great middle ground for carnivores and vegan alike. Nice ambiance, interesting chairs.The chicken was so good! From presentation to flavor, to texture! Go Fricken!The crispy duck was tasty, sauce was spot on, but the texture had more resemblance to crispy pork.The papaya salad was just ok.Overall would go again!

This is my wife's favorite vegetarian restaurant.  We started coming here years ago and the food quality is always high.  As a meat eater I can always find many options that are tasty.  My only criticism is the  mixed drinks are on the small side and a little pricey.
Very good vegan Thai food.Great collection of drinks and cocktails.A bit pricey though.

Just went back here whilst in town.. it had been 4 years since the last time! Talk about consistency! It's just how I remember it if not better. I love the modern art on the walls and the cozy seating plan. We ordered the shrimp green curry and the ginger chicken and we absolutely loved it! The sticky rice really paired well with our dishes. The rice portions are kinda small.. we should have ordered 3 rice orders for the 2 of us.. will do so next time!The mango sticky rice dessert is impeccable. It's a must when you eat here!!!Service is pleasant and extra fast. The food is a little pricey but I still think for the quality it's worth it.

Honestly, I hate giving a restaurant a poor rating, especially when the food as amazing - truly delicious.  However, the service was honestly one of the worst I've ever had and I actually did contact the restaurant personally first, but got no response. So off to yelp I go!THere were 4 of us and we made reservations.  Although we were seated at our reservation time, we waited about 30 minutes to put our order in (during which time no one greeted or acknowleged us to let us know they would be with us).  After our order was taken, we did receive our food within a reasonable amount of time, however no one came by even once to check on us or see if we wanted more drinks or anything else to eat (which we would have ordered both of).  I tried to flag one of the staff down several times and was ignored.  We finished our meal and sat at our table for a good 45 minutes with obviously empty plates, while the staff walked back and forth past us (we were having a business dinner and had a lot to discuss, so we just talked about that while we waited).  At one point when we ran out of things to talk about, I even tried to follow a waiter so that I could get them to bring us the bill and was ignored.  About an hour AFTER we finished eating (not after we sat down), someone finally came to get our dishes and did not offer us dessert, just left.  I then had to, once again, relive the experience of trying to flag someone down to PAY.I was saddened as I was so very excited to visit this restaurant, but the amazing food was severely eclipsed by the more than terrible service we experienced.  We were there for 2 and a half hours, and about an hour and 45 minutes of that time was purely spent waiting for service or trying to track down one of the staff.  I completely understand that places get busy and things get behind, however there is no reason for anyone to ever have to wait over an hour after they finish their meal to have their plates cleared and have to pay, or wait 30 minutes after they sit down simply to be acknowleged.

worst staff in the city who ignores customerzero star would be more appropriate.A waitress looks the other way not to serve people... shameful and disgusting.Do not spend money on a restaurant with such bad employees and attitude.They are tons of other place with proper service  and class.

I surprised a friend by bringing her here for her birthday. The menu is extensive and everything looked wonderful. I was tempted to just say yes, when they asked what I wanted. The wait staff was very nice and accommodating. The cocktails looked beautiful and very creative. The food was just about perfect. The desserts must have been made with magic, because I have never tasted any vegan desserts that were that good. I will definitely be back, at least one more time before I leave Montreal.

In town from Houston, this was the best vegetarian Thai food I've ever had. We had great service and tried probably 10 different dishes.  Everything we had was super tasty! We're going back again during our short stay in Montreal, I think I could eat here every night!

I'll start with why I didn't give ChuChai 5 stars instead of 4: the restaurant is small and feels a little cramped. The tables are very close in proximity...enough to hear a conversation without trying to. Oh and the lighting is terrible, darkness far beyond creating an "intimate ambiance".However, the food was simply delicious. I am normally a meat lover (especially when dining out) but decided to come here to try something different. At ChuChai, it's "something different" in the best kind of way! Their menu offers a wide variety of choice (both main meal and appetizer). The food is marinated & flavored to near perfection! Their "faux beef" does taste like beef - but with an edge!

Having read the previous reviews before trying this place, I felt pretty confident that it would make a great location for a friend's birthday dinner. The only negative comments I saw were regarding service, which is not something I'm too bothered by, so I didn't think twice about booking a reservation. Now the funny thing is that I actually thought the service was good. The staff were friendly and the food came quickly (possibly too quickly, but I'll get to that in a second). The problem I had with ChuChai was the food. It was just so...mediocre. Here's a breakdown:First, the menu offers very specific dishes that focus on one or two items, so it really necessitates having to order more than one thing to have a "complete" meal. It was difficult to find a dish that had both vegetables and tofu/faux meat, which I found frustrating since I don't want to eat just a bowl of plain vegetables or just a bowl of tofu. All to say that the menu is best experienced by multiple people who are willing to share. Second, the menu gives one star for "spicy" and two stars for "very spicy". I ordered a one star dish (tofu in peanut sauce with crispy spinach) while my friend ordered a two star (rice noodles with vegan duck in chili sauce). We also split a plate of mixed vegetables, which had no stars. My dish did not have even the faintest hint of spice and my friend's had only what could be described as the memory of it. The mixed vegetables were not only "not spicy", but utterly unpsiced - just bland. To be fair, the server did tell us that she did not find the dishes to be spicy herself, but then why does the restaurant have such a ridiculously inaccurate labelling system? Finally, in terms of the quality of the food, we were unimpressed. The tofu in peanut sauce was extremely sweet. The crispy spinach had visible sugar sprinkled on it and the peanut sauce tasted like it was made with syrup. It was the kind of overdone flavour I would expect from a cheap roadside restaurant, not one where the (relatively small) dish cost $18 and didn't even come with rice. My friend's rice noodles tasted old, like they had been cooked in advance (which wouldn't be surprising since it took barely five minutes for our three dishes to arrive). The chili sauce tasted like it came from a bottle - generic and unflavourful. To be fair, the mock duck was excellent, but it was really the only good thing about that dish. We decided to skip on dessert, having had such an underwhelming experience at dinner. All in all, after tax & tip, our three dishes came to over $70 (no drinks). What can I say, I guess I'm in the minority when it comes to ChuChai, but I just don't get the hype. TL;DR: The food is not good - either too sweet or bland. Don't trust the menu's "spicy" ratings - even the highest rating has zero kick. Service is good. Price is much too high for both the quality and quantity of the dishes.

ChuChai does it right. It's obvious from the fact that it's one of the few vegan restaurants that have survived St. Dennis over the past few years. Most of the other establishments have disappeared far from the memories of picky eaters.It's also one of the few Asian vegetarian restaurants that aren't weird, kooky or too "out there" for the carnivores. It's clean, classy and sticks with a traditional menu that's meant to be simple yet impressive. Took my Chinese mom and aunt, who were both extremely skeptical, after a visit to Aux Vivres earlier that week. The weren't interested in trying another vegan restaurant and questioning the ingredients. Yet within the first few bites, they were blown away by the salted 'fish' fried rice, which was made with glutinous rice. They also loved my Panang 'beef' curry, with it's delicious red coconut sauce. The spring rolls were outstanding too, and filled with fresh vegetables. Everything was just perfectly flavoured. ChuChai will always be one of my Montreal favourites.MUST TRY: I won't say too much, but the five-flavoured finger food is a fun treat!SUMMER: Have a cocktail on the terrace after shopping on the strip.

Meh. I was so excited to have Thai food because I had been craving something soupy and/ or carby.We arrived around 5 p.m. and got outdoor seating because of the nice weather. I ordered the tom yum soup with shrimp ($6CAD) and the stir-fried noodles with duck ($16CAD, I forget the actual name, but it's listed right under the pad thai on the menu), while MC ordered the pad thai ($16CAD).Soup (3/5): Looked good, tasted fine. The shrimp was really weird, though. I'm not sure how to describe it, other than maybe a bit of a soapy taste? In retrospect, I should have gotten tofu or veggies instead of the shrimp.Duck noodles (2.5/5): While the duck was decent, the noodles were pretty bad. They were hard and cold, undercooked and salty. For a while, I was just picking at the veggies because those were the only ingredient with some moisture that the rest of the dish lacked. Pad thai (4/5): I've always been a fan of vegan/ vegetarian pad thai, and this did not disappoint. In fact, it was the redeeming factor of the meal, food-wise. I ended up eating all of MC's leftovers, hehe. There are also prix fixe options, but I believe those were $50CAD/ person, which is vastly overpriced for Thai food, IMO.
Who thought vegan could be so good? The chef is an artist. The dishes were tasty, full of flavor. - and very unique.

The place is very good with a lot of options. I really liked basil egg plant with pilaf of rice. The peanut curry was little more on the sweeter side as per my taste buds. Tom yum soup was good to start with.
Great place,Highly  recommend. .no words...awesome food and amazing drinks. Duck and beef curry is a must

Delicate and nice vegetarian fare. The ambiance and service were also good. Food was good but serving size a bit small. So after ordering a "normal" amount, we had to top up more which meant longer wait time. All in all, good experience.

After reading all the raving reviews, I decided to try ChuChai myself. I took the "crispy" duck dish, which seems to be a favorite. It was bluffing, texture and taste were both telling me "ok, they lied, this is actually duck". Probably the most realistic vegan meat I've ever tasted. And the skin (fried soya sheets) added an extra touch of realism and flavor. The portion of duck was unfortunately small, so I also got a side of crispy spinach (which was so good, highly recommend!). I loved the meal, but the prices are steep for the small portions you get. However, it's definitely a great place to impress your vegan date.

Had their pad Thai and it was absolutely delicious! Probably one of the best pad Thais in the city. Also tried their mango salad but wasn't a fan - it was a little too sour for me, and I found it to be expensive for what it was. Would go back again to try some of their other dishes (and re-order that pad Thai).

100% VeganMy first time in Montreal was made quite memorable, in large part, due to my experience at ChuChai. Not only this, but the restaurant had a nice ambiance and the food was sooo good. When traveling in a new city I always like to sit at the bar so I can talk with the bartender about the best places to eat, drink, and experience local culture. Though, sometimes it's hit or miss whether you actually get someone who is willing to take that time to chat with you. When I told the bartender, Elise, that I was from out of town, she immediately took interest in helping me find everything I was looking to do on my adventure. She began writing a list of local places to check out, based on my interests, along with notes on their distinguishing features...and the list did not disappoint. The exceptional service I received from Elise was equally matched by the chef. The food was fresh with clean and distinct flavors. I got the:- Kari Puff: a deep fried philo triangle with a samosa like filling- Deep Fried Dumplings (can't remember which): served with the best sweet and spicy sauce ever - Green Curry with White Rice: it was on the specials menuAll in all it was a great experience accompanied by great food. Thanks Elise!

Hands down, the best began Thai food I've ever had. I was nervous about the faux shrimp in my Pad Thai but the texture was complementary to the noodles and the flavour subtle. Every bite was perfect and the portion was big but not extreme like some noodle dishes.My husband had the Red Curry Duck and it was unreal. Seriously. I've never had real duck but the faux was amazing. Our Five Flavour Finger Food starter blew us away, as well. The decor and atmosphere are definitely in the upscale side, making this a great place for a birthday or anniversary dinner. Can't wait to come back here!

O.M.G.  BEST VEGAN FOOD EVER....we walked in on a sat nite, without a reservation and surprisingly were accomodatedservice was outstanding.  the drinks..very very good.  the lychee mojito was really yummy, i think it had a hint of an apple syrup in there...i had the curry duck which was really good and my friend had the green curry with the shrimp, shes not vegan, nor is she vegetarian and she actually stopped after she had a bite to make sure this was vegetarian for me because she couldn't believe it.the appetizers we had were the peanut skewers (amazing) and the 5 flavor appetizer which sounded odd initally, but wow, what amazing flavors (not very filling, but very cool to eat).  This place was just blow me away outstanding..and I come from Chicago that is really known for their vegan food....
Food is good, on the expensive side and now a days i feel like there are much better vegan places

Great food and lovely decor I really loved the place ! Would have given a full 5 stars if it not for the waiter, he was extremely pushy and in a span of 10 min came 3 times to ask us if we were ready to order while we were still glancing at the menu, I  did not appreciate that, my friends weren't comfortable either... again though great food!

I came here on the recommendation that it had great vegan food. My partner and I did not enjoy most of the food and drink ordered. Maybe it was because we were there 30 mins before the kitchen closed, but that shouldn't matter. The peanut sauce used on the fried tofu tasted like Peter Pan, it was so sugary, and the pinot noir had been open for days. My pad thai was fine, thankfully, but only average. I would probably not give this place a second try.

This was a bit of a disappointment. I had the table d'hote and was excited to try a number of dishes. I believe the duck is what they are famous for and it is so so. There is too much crust on the mushrooms and the sauce is too sweet. The other dishes were pretty good but in general most items were overly sauced. Dessert was great though and the service was excellent. Overall I believe this is a great restaurant but I the reviews make it out to be better than reality.

We were recently in Montreal for 10 days and we ate here four times.On our first visit, we were starving and wanted to try everything. So we asked for recommendations from a kind and friendly member of the ChuChai staff. To start, we had the Kiao Satay (dumplings in a peanut sauce) and the Waan Krob (crispy and spicy seaweed). We then had the Lemongrass Soup with chicken; one with and one without coconut milk, both delicious. For our entrees, we had the Beef Penang and the Crispy Duck with Spinach. Everything was phenomenally delicious, but the Beef Penang was particularly outstanding.On subsequent visits, we ordered the same main dishes (they were that good!), but varied the appetizers slightly. Nothing disappointed. If you're vegan or vegetarian, this is a must-try. Even if you aren't, you won't be disappointed by the beautiful environment, delicious food, and wonderful staff.

We went out for dinner here last night. My brother and I didn't realize all the dishes were vegan and made with faux meat until we sat down. We had the Crispy Duck Curry and the Coconut Beef Curry. I have to say that the food tasted great and the faux meat was totally not a problem. Be adventurous and try it! Also, the servers were wonderfully pleasant and offered helpful recommendations. There were only two negative points. The prices were a tad high (about $18 per curry dish). And, the restaurant is popular and had all the tables reserved (on a Wednesday night no less!) so we had to sit at the bar. You might want to make a reservation ahead of time.

My husband and I LOVED eating at Chu Chai on our recent trip to Montreal. Even though Montreal has a heavy French influence, I've never been a fan of French food so I searched for Asian food on Yelp. Chu Chai did NOT disappoint. I am a vegetarian, so I loved having so many options. My husband is a heavy meat eater and really loved it at as well! On weekdays between 5-7 pm, they have half priced cocktails as well. We had basil and bell pepper fried rice, "chicken" and basil curry, Tom yum soups, and these mini spring rolls with sweet and sour sauce (sorry I can't remember the official names of all the dishes). Everything was absolutely delicious, and we cleaned our plates!

Fun experience! Well worth trying for meat eaters and trying the fake meat. Some of the items don't need it. The beef coconut curry was delicious without. The crispy duck, albeit mimics the duck I wouldn't say was exceptional but alright. The springrolls were good as well. Good experience to be had, wasn't cheap but try it out and see.

Thanks to my vegetarian friend, I tried ChuChai a few years back. Honestly, we used to go to the "bistro" side, which was much less expensive, until they changed the menu and our favorite (duck in red curry with tomatoes and pineapple sauce), so we transferred to the formal dining room restaurant, which tends to be expensive for my taste.That being said, the spring rolls with peanut sauce, the eggplants in basilic sauce and the duck in red curry sauce tastes like heaven! (Ça goûte le ciel!)

If I had to recommend to a friend a list featuring the best vegetarian restaurants in Montreal, ChuChai would definitely make the top 3! It offers a delicious selection of tasty meals which may please vegetarians and meat-eaters alike. Although the price is moderately high for a restaurant of its category, they offer a remarkable service, smiles all around, and some of the best food in town; a wide selection of faux-meat, noodles, salads and more. If you happen to stop by and still have some space left for dessert after your meal, I recommend the chocolate avocado mousse as well as the thai tea.

I can't believe its not chicken...For those of you to afraid to try veggiterrean food because you need your meat, and you love the taste, well fear not, Chu chai to the rescue.Cut tofu and marinate it to appear and taste like chicken and shrimp. Fried banana was divine. Fried mushrooms and peanut dumplings scrumptious. Bring your own wine makes it an easy choice, make this place affordable. Bring a date, hmmm perhaps, but its very casual, so save it for someone you feel comfortable. There is a 2nd side to the resto, which is not a byow, and a little more intimate.
Went with a group of vegetarians and meat eaters. Everyone loved it. Their faux-meat had a similar texture to the real thing. Good curries, pad Thai, and sticky rice. Will be back again.

I have been to ChuChai 5 times now. Trust me on this, get the sticky rice and the crispy duck! I would have given them 5 stars but the last time I was there, the food arrived cold and we asked them to reheat it. It came back to the table just as cold the second time.The patio is a great people-watching spot in the summer plus it's bring your own wine which helps keep the cost down seeing as it is a tad overpriced.
Love this place!! Favourite restaurant ever!! Even meat eaters leave happy!
An absolute vegetarian's dream. One of the best veggie spots in Montreal by far.

Just went today with friends and the foods were pretty disappointing. I ordered the Royal Pad Thai for $16 minus taxes and it is too dry, cold and nothing special. The ones I ate at Thai Express were much better fresh and hot and also less expensive.  Also, the menu does not have much varieties. For sure, I am not going back and not going to recommend anyone to go lol. :X

We were looking forward to trying Chuchai, being the number 1 place on Yelp for Thai food in Montreal. However, unfortunately, we were quite disappointed. We ordered the Tom Yum soup, Pad Thai and 3-flavoured beef dish. Everything was lukewarm at best. When we told the waitress that the food was cold, she just looked at us blankly and was unsure what to do. We had to explicitly ask her if the food can be heated up.Likewise, the beef dish was classified as "spicy" but had nothing more than a sweet taste. Overall, it was a nice vibe, but a very uninspiring meal.The restaurant wasn't terribly busy (it was a late Saturday night), so the wait staff need to pay more attention to when the food is ready in the kitchen and bring it out on time.

Absolutely delicious food. As a vegetarian with vegan inclinations, I tend not to rely on meat substitutes as a primary source of nutrition...but my goodness, does ChuChai pull it off with flying colors. I would even say that what I ordered ended up being some of the tastiest vegetarian Thai food I've ever had (tasted like fresh herbs were used, too). This made for a lovely night.Montréal me manque terriblement...et lorsque je reviendrai, je commande du ChuChai à emporter de suite :).

Came here on a quiet Wednesday night. Excellent and friendly service and delicious food. Enjoyed my tasty General Tao tofu dish and my omnivore boyfriend LOVED his 'duck' dish, he was very impressed. Recommended!

After initially reviewing this place, I went to ChuChai a few more times and became very disappointed.The food is good and consistent, and the staff remains kind. However, after being smacked with high-priced bills, I realized that the portions are too small for what you are paying for. I feel that this place is a trap for vegetarians since it's not always easy to get good veggie meals in many restaurants. Also, I've been experiencing very slow service here which can be rather annoying.I gave ChuChai a few chances, but they failed me. There are other Thai restaurants that offer good food for reasonable prices; I rather go there instead.
This is a very nice place. Food was delicious, the service was very good and the food was prepared very quickly, we just waited like 5 min. Very suitable for family. Highly recommended.

ChuChai is amazing, not just for its uncanny yet playful renditions of fake meat, but for the flavor combinations that make it great cuisine, meat or not.First, let's talk about the meat, made of tempeh, tofu, seitan, and other such things. The beef has genuinely beefy texture, that of braised meat that falls apart at the touch of a fork. The duck has flesh-like striations and even emulates that layer of fat between the meat and the skin. The shrimp is probably the least realistic, but playful with pink stripes painted on to the curved little nuggets.Our table started with an order of poutine, not knowing what to expect. It was a marvelous play on the classic with crispy fries blanketed in a Thai mock beef salad, piquant with lemongrass, lime and herbs, then topped with diced avocado and arugula. That was my favorite item of the night, though the spicy and flavorful beef panang curry was a close second. The crispy duck came in a sweet and sort of boring soy-based sauce, but the duck was a marvel to be admired. Husband particularly loved the garlicky eggplant with faux shrimp and hoarded it mostly to himself. And the spicy chicken in peanut sauce came with an outstanding crispy spinach reminiscent of kale chips. The only dud was pad thai which didn't live up the excitement of the other dishes. Come here and be astounded.

The food, service and menu selection -- all excellent.  But I can't offer more than three stars given the high price of the food and the complete disconnect between the menu and the decor.  This could be a wine bar, an Indian restaurant, a pasta house or a late-night coffee and desert place and they wouldn't need to change a thing.  You could put this place in a police line and not be able to pick it out as the vegan Thai place.Spice levels were underwhelming, too.

My boyfriend and I went to Montreal for the first time this summer and when searching for a vegan place... we had found our match. Laid back/modern ambiance. Even though we went on a very busy night (I think it was a Wednesday) they took care of us. The food was superb! BEST VEGAN THAI EVER! Too bad you are a very expensive airplane ride away. My favorite dish was the beef panang curry and the best dessert I've ever had was the coconut milk tapioca. YUMMM! Cannot wait to return!

Had a great dinner here last night. The Mai Thai Tini hit the spot to start, along with the Miang Kram appetizer, which is a must order - it pops in your mouth. Also liked the dumpling with peanut sauce. My entree was a bit too spicy - I ordered the shrimp with eggplant, and they include some quite spicy small peppers, but I picked some of them out and it was fine. I appreciated the brown rice option. I also enjoyed the dessert of Thaipioca pudding made with coconut milk. It was a really original and interesting thai experience, especially for being all vegan.

If traveling to another country with the primary purpose of eating here at ChuiChai, doesn't say how FABOULOUS this place is, I don't know what will!We've been coming here for years and although it has changed a bit, the food is still dynamite! The flavors are amazing. The food is creative. The prices are reasonable. If you are in heading into Montreal, and are looking some delicious Thai food- this is the place to go! I can't wait to go back again! Bring those work trips on; I'm hungry!  =)

Oh, thank you, ChuChai for existing. You give me hope there are other vegans in the world who care about quality, taste and elevated dining experiences. I had the Pad Thai, which was delicious though I wish it had been a little spicier (You can ask). My husband had the crispy duck, which made everyone at the table moan with delight. The atmosphere is elegant, cozy and everything vegan dining is missing. Thank goodness, there's no juice bar (I mean, I like juice but why does every vegan restaurant also have to be a juice bar?)! I also had a refreshing cocktail, but alas I cannot remember the name. Friendly service, reasonable wait times. So highly recommended - especially since I wouldn't be ashamed to take my non-vegan/vegetarian friends to eat there.
The food was delicious but the portions were way too small for the price. It's an "upscale" restaurant, which is expected, but vegan cuisine needs to have a somewhat big, definitely healthy portion.

Used to be one of my favourite restaurants in Montreal but last time I went I was so disappointed. My friend and I ordered what we normally like to order but nothing we got was very good. We mentioned it when we were paying the bill and the guy obviously didn't care all that much.Too bad but I wouldn't spend that much money on food that's mediocre at best now.Chu chai, whatever you changed in the way you make you food, change it back. Everything was delicious before.

Outside of some of my own veg dishes (I can assure you I'm in no way biased), this place is probably the best vegetarian meal I've had in a restaurant to date.  It's not easy to do good creative veg dishes, but here, it was exceptional.  You don't even think about the fact that you're not eating meat.  We had the fried dumplings with sweet and spicy sauce and the "shrimp" hot and sour soup with lemon grass to start.  Both excellent.  For the mains we had the crispy duck with soy sauce and spinach, which I marveled over (probably the reason for this 5 star) and the spicy rice noodles with black mushrooms.This place put veg dining on a whole new level for me.  New York restaurants now have something to shoot for.

This is a vegan restaurant but good enough for non vegans to eat here too. They served water pretty quickly. I would get a couple of appetizers because the mains are not so big. For appetizers I got the Tom Kha soup with shrimp. And the breaded mushrooms. Both were amazing. For the main I got the red curry coconut chicken. And brown steamed rice. Also amazing! I'm not impressed with the service as they screwed up both my appetizer and my main meal. For my appetizer they brought the wrong thing so I just had to wait for them to bring the right order. But for the main, they brought me an extremely spicy dish instead of my order. I was sharing food with my toddler. He took 1 bite of it and burned his mouth! He refused to eat anything but rice after that. So it was an unpleasant experience for me. They offered him soy milk to bring down the burning. Besides that, once I got my correct order, the food was indeed very tasty.

Excellent food, good service, just a little expensive for lunch but worth the experience, specially compared to all those so called healthy vegan places that charge crazy prices . Will be back for sure

So I took 2 new friends there for the first time. While we were waiting for our table we sat at bar and bartender recommended us drinks considering our taste. Drinks were amazing!!  Waiters were all extremely nice, service food drinks a 10!! Thank you for making my girl's bday very special.

Consistently EXCELLENT, every year for as long as I can remember coming here (annually for 15 years at least). Chu Chai does vegan mock meats extremely well. Even if you have had similar and are not a big fan of mock meats it is worth going. They really have figured out how to get the right balance of flavors and textures. The service has always been consistent as well. Just the right amount of attention. Unfortunately, at one time you could bring your own wine, but not anymore. The wine and cocktail selections are good though. I think we have now tried everything on the menu, except for the papaya salad (which we meant to try this time, but forgot!). Must Try: Miam Kram (sp?) and the #99 Special (secret name from the old menu!).
Superb faux-meat restaurant in Montreal. Great service. I've been coming here for years.Their salt and pepper shrimp, three flavor beef, and duck pad thai are fantastic.A definite must-try.

Love this place! It was delicious, so much flavour in everything we ate! Our waitress along with the other staff were amazing, really great service! My fiance and I will definitely be going back! It was all vegan!!!

We were psyched to find a veggie restaurant, and all the great reviews got our hopes up.  Unfortunately, the food was run-of -the-mill and uninspired.  The biggest downfall...the waitress explained that they do not cook with garlic or onions there...she wasn't sure why, but she reassured us that the flavors would wow us anyway.  They didn't.  The sauces were bland and boring.  The soy substitute was mushy.  They need to amp up the creativity and for God's sake cook with the alliums!!

Absolutely delicious!!! We're visiting Montreal and decided to give this place a try and were truly impressed. Absolutely amazing food. We skipped starter but shared the Chicken Red Curry, Beef Yellow Curry (all dishes are vegetarian meats) and a side of vegetable fried rice. The chicken dish was very tasty but the beef curry even moreso. Absolutely melt-in-your-mouth delicious. Even the veggie fried rice had large pieces of veggies in it. I cannot fault anything about the whole meal - wonderfully tasty and all veggie too!My husband also ordered the tapioca dessert which came with a thin layer of coconut cream on top. Oh my, that too was light, tasty and simply fabulous.If you're a vegetarian or vegan you should eat here. If you're a meat eater, you should REALLY eat here, it'll teach you why people give up eating meat when there are such delectable alternatives without the cruelty and chemicals.I cannot recommend ChuChai highly enough - just go.....Now! .....Seriously!

I'm obsessed with the green curry and "shrimp." The food is consistently awesome.  My only complaint is that they don't have more locations. It can be hard to get a table if you want to go for a spontaneous dinner, and every time I've visited it's been a bit cramped.  So it's not a place to chill out and have a relaxed evening. The food is worth it though.
Very good Asian cuisine, standard. The inside is nice with a large bar. I hit this place at lunch in a Tue and it was just me and another couple. May be more of a dinner/takeout place.

Although the concept is great the food was just too expensive. The fake meats were quite convincing, the food was delicious, and the restaurant itself was pretty cool. I just don't know why it cost so much.

Some people say it is not authentic Thai food. Who cares? Thai food is full of fish sauce and shrimp paste anyway! We went to Chuchai on our last night in Montreal. It was not cheap but it was really tasty and a great experience altogether. They have menus in English and French which were very convenient for us. We started with the curry puffs and the deep fried seaweed in a sweet and spicy sauce. The curry puffs were nice enough but looked and tasted more or less like samosas. On the other hand, the seaweed dish was amazing! Then we had the fake chicken with peanut sauce and fried spinach. That was so delicious. The spinach was also a bit sweet and unlike anything I tasted before. Very delicate flavours. We also had some red curry which was great too. The sticky rice is absolutely perfect. Our dishes rated 2 on the scale of 3 for spiciness but we did not find then spicy at all. We were told that they do not use dairy or eggs in the cooking, but still use milk in coffee and honey in desserts so it is not yet a vegan restaurant but hopefully they will move to. Totally worth trying in Montreal.
Chu Chai is the kind of place that makes you question whether or not you could actually convert to Veganism. If there were a CC on every block, there's no doubt I could.
I visited this place a year ago. The waiter was very nice. I just do not like the food there. It did not really taste like thai. The food there is very exotic to me.
Wow, all vegan, delish!!! The waiter was extremely friendly and very helpful to new visitors to Montreal. Will go there again.

I use to live this place. The restaurant use to have two sections, a cheaper side and and more upscale expensive side. The food was great and you could usually get a decently priced meal on the less expensive side. Today is the first time I come back after their renovations and their prices appear to have increased by over 25%. They used to be, I believe, limit on the price for what they offered. Now they are just overpriced.
Delicious! Everything we ordered was so good. The curry is great. I had the "chicken" and it did not taste fake at all. The mango salad was great too. Everyone in my family enjoyed - which is a feat!

I've been vegetarian for my entire life and I gotta tell you people straight up -- this place sucks. I'm sorry it really does. Chuchai is pretty much the same as Chuch which is next door ... except you pay more because it is a tad fancier and a little more formal but in any case (to reiterate) this food is simply substandard when you take into consideration the price that they're asking. If you want really salty fake meat, average concepts, flavourless yet overly salty sauces, microwaved food (I know right?!?) served by slow wait staff, bad music and uncomfortable plastic chairs this is right up your dystopian alley and is probably just the place for you. I really don't know how they have existed for so long seeing as how there are so many excellent vegetarian restaurants in the Plateau, let alone the entire city. If East Asian vegetarian cuisine is what you're looking for, don't get it here ... go somewhere else like Yuan Vegetarian or Su Shian Yuang. Sorry to be so harsh but I tells it like it is. Peace.

Loved every minute of this meal and we walked almost two miles to get there.  The staff was super attentive, and the food was delicious.  Loved the chicken satay and spring rolls.  I got the pad thai which was perfectly done and my daughter got a chicken broccoli dish that was delicious also.  For the vegan lover and anyone else, one of our favorite meals in Montreal.

Stopped by for dinner with group of friends. Place is clean and classy with a good ambiance. Menu has varied Thais dishes - something for everyone including vegetarians. Had an opportunity to try vegetarian and non vegetarian entrees - for some reason the later also had tofu in them. Don't think that was warranted. The service was friendly and attentive. Dishes were not too spicy but we were able to add tongue taste with side condiments.  Overall, good value for the money and clean place.  Something for every pallet Thai style.

Oh Chu Chai Chai? What's up? Why's that price so high? Yes, I did. I went all the way back to 1983 to rock that Kajagoogoo reference.  And yes, thank you, I sleep very well at night. ChuChai makes some delicious vegetarian Thai food.  That is still true... HOWEVER, the combination of an increasingly more pedestrian menu and a slightly ridiculous pricing level take away a lot of the goodness found in my previous premise.Aside from the somewhat diminutive portions, you will be in vegvana at first bite of pretty much any of the curries here.  The crispy duck is a culinary masterpiece - as an omnivore I have to profess preferring it to the, you know - "other" kind.  Uh huh - really.  Always try the chefs specials as they most are just that - truly special. Service is reasonable - nothing to write home about / nothing to remove stars about. Getting there late in the evening seems to be a bad idea if you want to catch the staff at the top of their game.Honestly - my only fault with the place is the drastic moves down the price quality curve.Are the owners of ChuChai members of the elite group of supervillains that are fabled in song and story (aka my Yelp reviews) as Vegtortionists? Those that hold the veggie and vegan community price hostage for daring to follow their moral compass?  Not yet, but another combo price hike/menu dulling will certain earn them a membership invite.

Normally my non-meat based diet revolves around plants, grains, and legumes, but mock meat is one of my guilty pleasures -- especially when it's done really well, as it is at ChuChai. The table d'hote menu is a bit spendy for those on a thriftier budget at $100 for two (and kind of confusing to figure out), but it's worth it for a splurge - you really get to sample a wide variety of menu items. Each person receives one alcoholic beverage and a small sampling of five different appetizers, then you essentially get four main-dish sized portions to split between the table, plus sides of rice. To top it all off, you get sample sized portions of three different desserts and coffee or tea to finish. Everything was delicious (and beautifully plated!), and I was stuffed to the gills by the end of the meal. The mock chicken with the peanut sauce and crispy spinach was a particular standout for me. Good company + table d'hote menu + warm summer evening + outdoor seating = the most fantastic way to spend my final evening in Montreal.

I am not vegetarian and I LOVED this restaurant! Their faux meat dishes were out of this world! I had gone with my equally carnivorous boyfriend and we couldnt believe how good this restaurant was! Service was amazing, food was delicious, atmosphere was great.They take your coats at the entrance too. Parking is a bit tricky however.

Ok ok, what am I doing at an all vegetarian restaurant? I am not vegetarian, and I actually love getting my protein through a thick steak or nice piece of fish just as much as the next guy. That doesn't mean I can't appreciate vegetarian cuisine and even enjoy it. It might help that my girlfriend at the time I visited ChuChai was a hardcore vegetarian herself.I don't necessarily remember all the food we ordered that evening, but the one item that always comes to mind when I think of ChuChai is the crispy duck! I know it has been mentioned in other reviews, but you can't go to this restaurant without trying it. It's that good. If you didn't know it was a vegetarian restaurant, you can almost assume that it's real duck!The chef at ChuChai has really created one of the most unique dining experiences around by coming up with a menu that includes vegetarian versions of all sorts of "proteins" and actually making them tasty, as well as visually and texturally appealing!

i ordered the kari puff which looked and tasted like indian samosas. the filling was pureed and was well spiced. i enjoyed the fresh salad on the side. as my main dish i ordered the pad keemoa with mock duck with 3 star spiciness which i LOVED. i think this was the best thai noodles ive tasted so far. the duck tasted realistic to me and was chewy. the noodles were chewy and flavorful. service was  prompt and staff refilled water frequently.

Upscale vegan Thai cuisine done well. I had a saute dish with mock chicken and veggies and rice, and my husband had a noodle dish with a few types of mock meat. Both were great, and we look forward to going back on our next trip to Montreal.

The crispy duck is out of this world. I still can't believe that everything was vegan. This is by far the best culinary experience in vegan cooking. The chocolate mousse made with avocado is again better than the real thing! Every time I travel to Montreal I will make sure to eat at ChuChai.  I love ChuChai.

We sat on the Chuch Bistro side, where you can eat both the bistro style food or the fancified Thai food that's available on the other side (no idea whether you can also eat both on the other side as I've only been once). The cocktail menu could've been a little more forthcoming. Titles of drinks don't really tell you anything, so we had to ask about all of them. I had a blushing geisha, which is a refreshing blend of vodka, sake, elderflower syrup, ginger beer and maybe a couple other things. It was super-sweet and also not particularly strong, but tasty enough.The food though. Oh man. So good. We started with a (mock) beef poutine with lemongrass and arugula (maybe? some kind of green). It was the best. Highly, highly recommended -- it doesn't perfectly match Thai food, but it has shadings of the flavor profile, so it doesn't contrast in a bad way. We had five people with a ton of dishes. The least successful was probably the pad thai. I knew going into ordering it that it was probably just there for the unadventurous whose friends dragged them there scared and distraught at the thought of fake meat and contemporary Thai, and so it's meant to comfort and console them. But, I can't not order a pad thai, so I did, and it was fine, but everything else was much better. The highlights for me were the crispy duck and the crispy spinach that came with the chicken in peanut sauce (my friend ordered the chicken ultra-spicy, and I couldn't try it because I'm a big spice wimp in comparison). The spinach is light and a little bit sweet and the crunch is perfect. The duck even replicated that fatty layer that happens between the skin and the meat, and the spice was rich and deeply flavored. There were also a couple of curries and an eggplant dish around the table, and a drunken noodles (pad kee mao). All fantastic, and no one missed the meat at all.Service was supernice, attentive, good water service. Rice was a touch overpriced for serving size, but whatever. I'll be back for sure.

Friendly greeting and good service. Papaya salad nice. Fried dumplings so-so. Pad Thai royale wonderful as were the green curry vegetables. Interesting chocolate avocado mousse and great coconut lime cake. Need to know more about house specialties -need recommendations. Portion sizes reasonable to small. Decent value for money.  Only down side is the atmosphere is a bit drab. Should be better for the price. A bit cafeteria like. Maybe some candles on tables or something to give it some warmth.

My macrobiotic/yoga teacher suggested me to check  this place when I first moved to Montreal in 2003. Ever since I've been a fan of this place. I can probably say I've eaten all of the items on the menu, all the mock meats and nothing has ever disappointed either my friends or me. Bring your own wine to make your meal more affordable (SAQ is nearby)

Hands down the best meal I had in Montreal and the best Thai food I think I've ever had. My friend and I got the $50 tasting menu and it was so worth it. Every single thing was unbelievably delicious and service was great. I would highly recommend the tasting menu if you are visiting so you can try as much as possible.

Can I give a 0? Because we arrive at 1:42 they were locking the door! They close at 2, which we knew. The person said, "there was no one here, so we are closing. Can you come back tomorrow?" Are you kidding me? We're hungry now, today.

I hate this place.BYOB.  Good service (for Montreal).  Relatively bad food (seriously, you people think this is good fake meat?).  The entire concept is ridiculous because it is hiding the inherent goodness in vegetables.  Small rice portions.
This restaurant is an amazing vegetarian restaurant, very innovative and a great vibe and atmosphere!  Will definitely return!

Fun decor. Good food. Lovely cocktail (though I agree it was weird they didn't list ingredients in the descriptions). The servers were very accommodating. My only real issue was the price. The servings were small, especially the rice. I felt like we ordered quite a bit of food but still weren't satiated.

Went there about five years agoJust recently came back, cuz my cousin from Vancouver was visiting and she's vegeterian, so we went to ChuChai...I'm quite impressed with this place, since everything is completely vegeterian, no meat no fish sauce whatsoever. That's a tall order if you're cooking thai food.I'd say it is a bit on the sweet side, everything is slightly sweet, I mean Thai cooking has a lot of sugar but this is is slightly sweeter than usual. Nothing a little lime can't fix really.we ordered pad thai, tofu with peanut sauce and fried spinach, mock penang beef, papaya salad, fried egg noodle which tasted like chow mein, and peanut sauce dumpling. The flavor is distinctly Thai, which is impressive, since a lot of dishes have fish sauce or some sort of prawn paste in it, and frankly i doubt i'm not sure i detect those hints of flavors missing... they found a way to substitute without cutting out the taste.The penang was the weakest, it lacked a bit, but the tofu with fried spinach is spot on. Being a meat eater it's not on top of my list but it's a nice place to go if you have a veggie friend, lol and we all have one or two of those :P

Chu Chai is so fabulously good that it wholly deserves every star it receives.  Even forgetting that all food is vegetarian and the 'duck' or shrimp that you are eating is actually soy protein, every dish is so wonderfully and delicately executed that the fact no animal had to perish to accomplish this goodness just adds to the appeal of this place.  I could eat anything from their menu forever and never miss meat.Unfortunately, we arrived too late for sit down service but the owners were so kind as to offer us take out instead and for which we were gleefully grateful.Standouts: crispy 'duck' with a sweet soy glaze, tofu in a peanut dressing, shrimp curry and the three mushroom pad siew.  (which is pretty much everything I ate at this meal)I regret that its 600kms away from home but you can be sure I will eat at Chu Chai at every visit to Montreal from now on.  WONDERFUL!

Have you ever been to a restaurant that only serves vegetarian food. How about a vegetarian restaurant that serves duck, chicken, and other meat products. Well at Chu Chai, you are served your choice of meat products that are actually made from soy protein. I love meat, but the soy chicken, duck and other meats that I shared with friends were some of the best "meat" I have had. It was served with rice of your choice. It was delicious. The serves was excellent and the restaurant  was a calming deemed lighting atmosphere. I would recommend this experience to anyone going to Montreal.

Eight or nine years ago on a visit to Montreal, I discovered Chu Chai (then in its former location) by accident while wandering the neighborhoods.  I was so thrilled to find an all veg restaurant serving fabulous food I dragged my traveling companion to meals there four or five times on our visit.Last summer I returned to Montreal -- a little bit older, a little bit wiser, different traveling buddy -- and made a point of heading back to Chu Chai.  The restaurant had moved a lot farther up Rue St. Denis and is now more remote.  Boo.  The restaurant is now much smaller and the decor not nearly as subdued or appealing.  Boo.  Looking over the menu, I didn't see the one dish I had obsessed over on my former visit: vegetarian shrimp with crispy basil and sticky rice.  Booooooo.  Oh. Em. Gee.  That shrimp was mouth watering, the basil deep fried into addictive crispy chips and dusted with sugar, and the sweet-ish sticky rice was super sticky and chewy and served in a banana leaf.  No longer on the menu.  Ordered a chicken and mixed veggies, husband ordered spicy beef.  They were good, but they didn't come close to the former quality of the food.  Totally disappointed.  Prices were rather steep, too, even at lunch.I wouldn't go out of my way on my next trip to Montreal to dine at Chu Chai, unfortunately.

A little more fancy than your average faux meat Asian place.  Portions are small but not too small.  Nothing they say is spicy is actually spicy.Make sure to try the fried spinach....I know if sounds weird...and it is.  Deep friend and lightly dusted in sugar, the spinach takes on a clear crystaline quality with a unique flavor.We also enjoyed the Pad Ke Mao with "duck" while the red curry was somewhat bland.All in all an excellent choice for vegetarians and quite flavorful.

Great place for vegans and non-vegans alike! Very unique dishes that I've never seen anywhere else. The seaweed appetizer dish is perfection - just try it!! And the crispy duck entree is crazy, I just don't know how they make it! It's all too good. The only thing is that it's very expensive for the amount of food that you get, and the sticky rice wasn't very good. Also I have a hard time with spicy food but the foods that they say are spicy on the menu actually aren't at all so just be aware of that.

VERY DISAPPOINTED! Microscopic lemongrass soup very expensive and worst than everywhere else, in version coconut - they literally put milk from can straight to bowl and served as the other dish. Fried dumpling was so dry that impossible to eat.  Vermicelli noodles with vegetables  had no taste at all (few vegetables with old sauce from wok, mixed with ordinary noodles). In summary: food worst than in cheap thai places for the double price. Service slow, bad and insolent. NEVER AGAIN!

We went here not realizing that the entire menu would be vegetarian. I was skeptical before ordering but was pleasantly surprised. I ordered the basil fried rice. I thought it was flavored well with a perfect amount of spicy-ness

ChuChai is le p'tit mort of vegetarian/vegan dining. The crispy mushrooms, dumplings in peanut sauce and soy sauce crispy "duck" were mouthgasmic. I sh*t you not. Omnivore, vegetarian, vegan... it doesn't matter, it is effing fantastic. Crap... I just drooled on my keyboard.Tips: For dinner I would make a reservation, although when we (4) just showed up we actually lucked out and got a patio table, on a Friday no less. If you go to the fancy-ish Chuchai (restaurant side) you can BYOW. Chuch, the "express" side is more casual but no BYOW.My only minor hiccup would be the cost vs. portion size. The small portions make it slightly pricey, and they could at least offer the mini steamed rice bowls for free at that price point. Still it was worth every penny and great for a dinner out... more for special occasions than on the regular so I don't go broke though.

The Thai restaurant has "closed" and changed the menu.  It seems like it still has the same owners and the menu is still vegan but it's now a upscale tapas restaurant.  So, this revue is about the new menu & restaurant.They have a lot of good menu items with varied ingredients and stlyes.  The night we were there, they must have had a lot of left over ingredients from the Thai restaurant because there were a lot of thai influenced recipes.We ordered 4+ plates and wine.  The wine was was one of the smallest servings I've had for $7 although decent.  The beer selection consisted of 3 options.The food was okay at best.  The flavors were a bit bland and needed some salt or maybe a bit of spice to top it off.  I tried the fish and chips and wasn't impressed.   Overall the food seems like a "oh, I've tried that" kind of experience.   The portions of the food (and wine) are ridiculously small so expect to spend a crap load of money to eat and drink.... Also expect to grab some food afterwards.tl;dr: Expensive, small portions but unique ideas with bland flavors.  I wish they made bigger plates of the good items.

My wife and I are vegetarians and we were looking forward to trying the "faux" meats on offer here. The menu features meatless duck, fish, chicken, and beef dishes. We tried a yellow curry beef dish and chicken with peanut sauce. Long story short: nothing short of culinary alchemy going on here. The "beef" and "chicken" looked like the real thing, tasted like the real thing, and had the mouth feel of the respective meats. SImply astonishing. The sauces were deliciously tangy, but not too spicy (I guess you could ask for more if you wanted), and the service polite and efficient.The best vegetarian restaurant I have ever been to, and there isn't even a close second. Bravo. We will really miss it when we return home!The place is BYOB, but fortunately, there's an SAQ right across St. Denis.

After the boyfriend and I suffered serious disappointment on finding ChuChai closed on New Years Eve, we finally made it in on our last night in Toronto and we were more than pleased. As a 20-year vegetarian, I remember when fake meat didn't even exist, so it doesn't tend to get me as excited as some folks, but this fake meat is worth it. It's well constructed, flavorful, and they get the texture as close as wheat-gluttenly possible. But it wasn't really the fake meat that got me going. They dishes were beautiful and thoughtfully prepared, from the chef's special appetizer of toasted coconut shreds, lime, peanut, and some magical sauce on a shiso leaf for bite-sized heaven to the ingenious breaded and fried seaweed shreds appetizer in a perfectly spicy sweet/hot sauce. I ordered the fried spinach on Yelp recommendation and we were shocked - how do they flash deep fry in so? And sweet with just a hint of pepper? Amazing. I have a hard time ordering when faced with so many options, but when we finally made our choice (duck with chilis and basil, chicken with spicy eggplant) I couldn't have asked for better - the vegetables were so thoughtfully cut and prepared, the sauces amazing. Service was just fine - suiting and upper-scale casual place such as this. A a large group made the evening louder than I would have liked, but it couldn't have been avoided. DO keep in mind that ChuChai is NOT BYOB like it's little cousin Chuch, and you won't be disappointed.
See my review of ChuChai (with beautiful photos) here:alltheveganthings.com/po…

My favorite vegan restaurant I've found thus far in Montreal. I brought my meat-loving boyfriend and his very traditional meat-loving mother here and they ADORED the food. Both of them were delighted and stunned at how the fake meat mimicked reality. My boyfriend even mentioned that he'd be able to go vegetarian if he could find more food like what he had here.
